## MATHEMATICS

9709/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 320]]<|/det|>
October/November 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 419, 225, 435]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 450, 764, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 466, 809, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 482, 566, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 498, 487, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 513, 364, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 528, 870, 558]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 558, 485, 573]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 573, 885, 603]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 603, 860, 633]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 666, 216, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 682, 388, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 75.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 697, 732, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 742, 92]]<|/det|>
Express \(x^{2} + 6x + 5\) in the form \((x + a)^{2} + b\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 529]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 510, 866, 530]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation \(y = x^{2}\) is transformed to the curve with equation \(y = x^{2} + 6x + 5\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 541, 526, 561]]<|/det|>
Describe fully the transformation(s) involved.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 3x^{2} - 4x + 4\) and a straight line has equation \(y = mx + m - 1\), where \(m\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 905, 139]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(m\) for which the curve and the line have two distinct points of intersection.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 136, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
In the expansion of \((a + bx)^7\), where \(a\) and \(b\) are non-zero constants, the coefficients of \(x\), \(x^2\) and \(x^4\) are the first, second and third terms respectively of a geometric progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 121, 282, 144]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(\frac{a}{b}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 141]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 92, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 534, 102]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = \frac{2x}{3x - 1}\) for \(x > \frac{1}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 115, 146, 133]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 114, 400, 133]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\operatorname {f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 920, 134]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 460, 185, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[188, 458, 584, 492]]<|/det|>
Show that \(\frac{2}{3} + \frac{2}{3(3x - 1)}\) can be expressed as \(\frac{2x}{3x - 1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 462, 920, 482]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 780, 186, 798]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 780, 316, 798]]<|/det|>
State the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 781, 920, 798]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
The first and second terms of an arithmetic progression are \(\frac{1}{\cos^{2}\theta}\) and \(-\frac{\tan^{2}\theta}{\cos^{2}\theta}\), respectively, where \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 144, 146, 163]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 139, 522, 166]]<|/det|>
Show that the common difference is \(-\frac{1}{\cos^4\theta}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 144, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 564, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the 13th term when \(\theta = \frac{1}{6}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 579, 104]]<|/det|>
The equation of a curve is \(y = 2x + 1 + \frac{1}{2x + 1}\) for \(x > -\frac{1}{2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 116, 304, 144]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}}\) and \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2\mathrm{y}}{\mathrm{dx}^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 123, 920, 142]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the stationary point and determine the nature of the stationary point.  [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 437, 91]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 186, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 510, 479, 528]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 510, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 78, 104, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 767, 102]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = \frac{1}{k} x^{\frac{1}{2}} + x^{-\frac{1}{2}} + \frac{1}{k^2}\) where \(x > 0\) and \(k\) is a positive constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 117, 146, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 116, 609, 136]]<|/det|>
It is given that when \(x = \frac{1}{4}\), the gradient of the curve is 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 149, 316, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 148, 106]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 78, 591, 123]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that \(\int_{\frac{1}{4}k^2}^{k^2} \left(\frac{1}{k} x^{\frac{1}{2}} + x^{-\frac{1}{2}} + \frac{1}{k^2}\right) \mathrm{d}x = \frac{13}{12}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 134, 316, 153]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(k\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 134, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]
